results.headline: Barely Literate, Roma Pupils Struggle for Schooling

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Our School

results.summary_short: “Our School” observes the feinting of small-town officials in rural Transylvania as they try to duck a mandate to integrate Roma children into the regular school system.

results.headline: From Real-Life Governor to Small-Town Sheriff

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Stand

results.summary_short: In “The Last Stand” Arnold Schwarzenegger plays the sheriff of a small town near Mexico who has to stop a drug lord headed for the border in a supercharged Corvette.

results.headline: Inside the Lives of Somali Pirates

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stolen Seas

results.summary_short: Stolen Seas” is a multifaceted investigation into the causes and consequences of Somali piracy.

results.headline: Twists and Turns in Becoming a Man: A Day in Baltimore

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of LUV

results.summary_short: “Luv,” directed by Sheldon Candis, follows a boy out for a day with his uncle, who wants to show his nephew how to be a man.

results.headline: Where Dread Throbs and Little Girls Scuttle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mama

results.summary_short: “Mama” is a horror ghost story that offers pictorial beauty, an atmosphere throbbing with dread and actors so good that you don’t want anyone to take an ax to them.

results.headline: Minimalism Wrapped in a Mystery

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Outside Satan

results.summary_short: “Hors Satan,” Bruno Dumont’s latest film, is set in the French countryside and uses natural sounds as a storytelling tool.

results.headline: When They Hammered Out Justice in the ’60s
results.display_title: Greenwich Village: Music That Defined a Generation

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Greenwich Village: Music That Defined a Generation

results.summary_short: Laura Archibald’s documentary, “Greenwich Village: Music That Defined a Generation,” looks at the folk musicians of the 1960s.

results.headline: Fighting for Light Amid Urban Noir

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Broken City

results.summary_short: The director Allen Hughes paints New York a darker shade of noir in “Broken City,” which traces the moral education of a cop who has shot a man dead and is forced to turn in his badge.

results.headline: The Past Is Haunting Them

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brief Reunion

results.summary_short: A bat strays into a house in the middle of a dinner party, as a sort of omen, in “Brief Reunion.”

results.headline: Midwives and Diehards Again Find the Spotlight
results.display_title: Birth Story: Ina May Gaskin and The Farm Midwives

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Birth Story: Ina May Gaskin and The Farm Midwives

results.summary_short: “Birth Story: Ina May Gaskin & the Farm Midwives,” a documentary, puts a halo over the natural childbirth experience.

results.headline: Bollywood Laughs at Corruption

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Matru Ki Bijlee Ka Mandola

results.summary_short: Vishal Bhardwaj’s “Matru ki Bijlee ka Mandola” shows a rich, drunken industrialist leading a demonstration against himself.

results.headline: A Horror Movie Parody

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Haunted House

results.summary_short: Marlon Wayans stars in “A Haunted House,” a horror movie parody directed by Mike Tiddes.

results.headline: Citizen Foment That Fed Egypt’s Arab Spring

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Uprising

results.summary_short: “Uprising,” directed by Fredrik Stanton, is a concise account of the revolution in Egypt.

results.headline: As Sea Gulls Hover, Three Old Friends Reunite for a Funeral

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fairhaven

results.summary_short: In Tom O’Brien’s “Fairhaven,” three old friends from a Massachusetts fishing village are reunited for a funeral.

results.headline: Unpacking the Pandora’s Box of Technology

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Welcome To The Machine

results.summary_short: “Welcome to the Machine” ponders technology’s impact on humans.

results.headline: Heavily Armed and Not All That Bright

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Baytown Outlaws

results.summary_short: In “The Baytown Outlaws,” with Eva Longoria and Billy Bob Thornton, a Southern shoot-em-up, the focus is on three trigger-happy brothers.

results.headline: First He Is Killed, and Then He Tells His Tale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Struck by Lightning

results.summary_short: “Struck by Lightning” kills its protagonist in the beginning of the film, then has him narrate the story from beyond the grave.

results.headline: A ‘Rigoletto’ Reunion Just Might Save the Day

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Quartet

results.summary_short: “Quartet” assembles a posse of lovable geezers in a palatial residence for aged artistes and entangles them in the mildest imaginable comic and dramatic situations.

results.headline: A Boyhood Friendship Fractured by War

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Best Enemy

results.summary_short: “My Best Enemy,” a World War II drama, follows the closely linked fortunes of two childhood friends: the heir of a Jewish gallery owner and a newly minted Nazi.

results.headline: A Passover Different From All Others

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Let My People Go!

results.summary_short: “Let My People Go!” tosses gay stereotypes into a Jewish holiday, adds the bedroom-door-banging beats of French farce, then piles on the dysfunction.
